Award.AwardTitle: LTREB: Social, Environmental, and Evolutionary Dynamics of Replicated Hybrid Zones in Swordtails (Teleostei: Xiphophorus) of Mexico's Sierra Madre Oriental
Award.AbstractNarration: The study of natural hybridization - the exchange of genetic information between species - is fundamental to further understanding how genes function within organisms and within the environment. Hybrids - crosses between different species - can also be used to identify specific genes associated with traits of interest and how these genes interact with environmental variation, ultimately shedding light on the genetic basis of disease and adaptation to environmental change. This project studies changes in behavioral decisions, communication signals, heat and cold tolerance, and population structure over 10 years in natural and experimental populations of swordtail fish, a longstanding model in genetics, physiology, and behavior. The two parent species are found at high and low elevations, hybrids at intermediate elevations. Experimental populations will seed first-generation hybrids along an elevation gradient. The predicted response at the high elevation site is that genes associated with cold tolerance will spread along with the communication signals and behavioral biases of the high-elevation species, and vice-versa at the low elevation site. The study will identify novel genes involved with decision-making, communication, and temperature tolerance, which may lead to applications in medicine and agriculture. Further, the data will address the extent to which specific, identifiable parts of the genome are responsible for adaptation to various environments. Collection and analysis of data will be accomplished with a structured summer mentorship program between undergraduate students and local K-12 students. Because of the long-term nature of the study, K-12 trainees will have the opportunity to become mentors themselves later in the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project represents the first half of a ten-year study of changes over time in a hybrid zone between two fish species based at the CICHAZ field station in Mexico’s Sierra Madre Oriental based at the CICHAZ field station. By studying gene interactions between species in both natural hybrid populations and experimental crosses, the project gives us an unprecedented window on how genes and environment shape social behavior and physiology.  The project has brought teams of scientists and students together from throughout the United States and around the world.  Key results so far include insights into the molecular basis of melanoma, a cause of lower survival in hybrids, and into the genetic and behavioral forces at play in determining whether species stay separate or exchange genes.  Long-term monitoring of river habitats, fish populations, and water temperatures is giving us a clearer picture of how human-induced change affects animals’ ability to adapt, whether those changes are at a global scale with a warming climate, or at a local scale through impacts on stream health from  farming and ranching practices. Outreach programs supported by this grant focus on science education for K-12 students and the general public, concentrating on how we can best manage the effects human activities have on the soil, water, flora, and fauna in the area. The main outreach event is the annual Days of Science and Sustainability that bring together some 150 community members and scientists as well as graduate and undergraduate students for three days of activities. The first day usually features presentations of visiting scholars’ research to help the community learn about the scientific process and their scientific findings.The second day of the annual event features a hike with learning stations set up to discuss topics such as soil regeneration, the importance of biodiversity, and water pollution. Day three provides workshops for youth (K-12) where they learn how to design experiments and observe their natural surroundings scientifically. Volunteer college students lead the annual science camps for children (ages 6 – 13), and helped establish hiking trails with informational markers that highlight the uses of flora for humans and in the ecosystem. This project has developed a long-term resource for genetic studies of behavior and adaptation, made sustainable by training and engagement of scientists and partners in the local community and throughout the US. By focusing on evidence-based education practices and training scientists starting in elementary school, these activities have succeeded in nurturing middle schoolers through college, college students through their doctorates, and graduate students to careers as independent researchers.
